reasoning: The critique targets a real argumentative hinge in Section 2: the essay leverages the prevalence of “moral catastrophe” judgments across views to motivate strong value-fragility and (implicitly) the multiplicative/near-zeroing picture. If that move fails, the rhetorical and intuitive case for “no easy eutopia” is meaningfully weakened. However, the paper’s main support doesn’t rest solely on this move: Section 3’s more structural ‘fussy vs easygoing’ analysis (bounded/unbounded scaling, aggregation of goods/bads, etc.) can still sustain much of the conclusion even if Section 2’s examples only show ‘suboptimality’ rather than ‘most value lost.’ Strength is moderate: it correctly identifies an equivocation between condemnation and near-total value-loss under the paper’s own cardinalization (the gamble test), but it doesn’t engage the paper’s stronger examples (e.g., animal suffering possibly outweighing gains) nor show that *plausible* moral views systematically assign only modest disvalue to such flaws. Relevance is high because it bears on Forethought’s Tier-2/3 agenda around whether flourishing is a narrow target and thus how much leverage ‘better futures’ work has relative to survival/x-risk work.
title: "Moral Disagreement Does Not Imply Massive Value Loss"
